previous_headings: What is the National Broadband Map (NBM) data set?
title: National Broadband Map (NBM)
text: NBM launched FCC November 20221 follows Form 477. Behind National Broadband Map, two datasets (see @fig-broadbanddata, ). use “Broadband Availability” dataset derived “Fabric” locations dataset (developed CostQuest). locations determined within Fabric locations data. dataset can derived multiple ways: States Providers. state level, data can split summaries “raw data”. summaries available geographies technologies (Fixed Broadband Mobile Broadband). every state, need access raw data technology. work, focused Fixed Broadband Availability data. NBM provides information scale “service” - location covered provider technology specific maximum speed. formatting approach one big changes compared Form 477. moved Cesus-block scale location-based scale (See @sec-BSL definition). Every location characterized : providing services (frn, provider_id, brand_name) description service (technology, max_advertised_download_speed, max_advertised_upload_speed, low_latency) Whether location residential, business Ways localize location (state_abbr, block_geoid, h3_res8_id) ingestion, keep h3_res8_id property, added date release timestamp provided filename (see data-raw/NBM.R get every details). exact coordinates every location part Fabric dataset. Within Broadband Availability data, can link record location Census Block (2020 vintage) H3 hexagon.

previous_headings: What is the National Broadband Map (NBM) data set? > A Quick Introduction
what: What is a Broadband Service Location (BSL)?
title: National Broadband Map (NBM)
text: broadband serviceable location defined “business residential location United States fixed broadband Internet access service , can , installed.” residential BSL includes residential structures, including structures (contain) housing units group quarters (terms defined United States Census Bureau). business BSL includes “non-residential (business, government, non-profit, etc.) structures property without residential locations expect demand Internet access service.” (source FCC2)

previous_headings: What is the National Broadband Map (NBM) data set? > A Quick Introduction
title: National Broadband Map (NBM)
text: NBM two big releases per year (June December) versions every two weeks take account challenges3. Sometimes release can faster (one per week) slower. FCC (April 2024) provide changelog releases versions (documentation major changes4).

title: FCC's Form 477
text: Simplifying access data usually matter opinion. data keep? data discarded? effective data analysis, important communicate decisions provide full story data.

title: FCC's Form 477
text: FCC reports Form 477 Fixed Broadband deployment. Broadband providers required file information: facilities-based broadband providers required file data FCC twice year (Form 477) offer Internet access service speeds exceeding 200 kbps least one direction.Fixed providers file lists census blocks can offer service least one location, additional information service. Source: https://www.fcc.gov/general/broadband-deployment-data-fcc-form-477 census block mentioned US census blocks 2010 vintage. Water census blocks also removed. Every row dataset matches specific service provided ISP census block. ISP can provides multiple services, different technologies different speeds census block. time period covered goes back December 2014. update June December every year December 2021.

title: FCC's Form 477
text: Broadband data FCC Form 477, data U.S. Census Bureau presented site offered free subject copyright restriction. FCC asks proper credit given: Source data: FCC Form 477 using data please follow simple guidelines. Source: https://broadband477map.fcc.gov/#/

title: FCC's Form 477
text: 477 data released multiple versions releases. took decision use ingest last release version. assuming versions consistent, selecting last version help homogenize dataset. also decided satellite data less important workflows, hence focused Fixed without satellite data. opinionated version perhaps suboptimal specific uses. Feel free look implementation making sure process reliable. provide code used generated data set .

title: FCC's Form 477
text: may notice strict regard data types. example, FRN 10 numbers (padded 0), ie CHAR(10), experience working previous ingestions shown consistently enforced rule. also decided provide data “” instead removing rows dubious values. decisions done analyst now.

title: Process FCC data
text: goal cori.data.fcc facilitate discovery, analysis, use FCC public data releases. package provides access data following sources: National Broadband Map (NBM) data1 Form 477 data

title: Process FCC data
text: can install development version cori.data.fcc GitHub : encountering problems devtools::check() related specific dependencies. Make sure latest version packages: - waldo - duckdb

title: Process FCC data
Process FCC data
text: Key uses: Access parquet files stored CORI s3 bucket, county: Access CORI-opinionated, Census-block level version latest NBM release:
code: guilford_cty <- get_county_nbm_raw(geoid_co = "37081") dplyr::glimpse(guilford_cty) #> Rows: 1,337,541 #> Columns: 14 #> $ frn                           <chr> "0001857952", "0001857952", "0001857952"… #> $ provider_id                   <chr> "130077", "130077", "130077", "130077", … #> $ brand_name                    <chr> "AT&T", "AT&T", "AT&T", "AT&T", "AT&T", … #> $ location_id                   <chr> "1344960789", "1344965855", "1344971572"… #> $ technology                    <dbl> 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, … #> $ max_advertised_download_speed <int> 10, 0, 10, 50, 50, 75, 50, 10, 50, 0, 10… #> $ max_advertised_upload_speed   <int> 1, 0, 1, 10, 10, 20, 10, 1, 10, 0, 1, 5,… #> $ low_latency                   <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, TRUE… #> $ business_residential_code     <chr> "X", "X", "X", "X", "X", "X", "X", "X", … #> $ state_usps                    <chr> "NC", "NC", "NC", "NC", "NC", "NC", "NC"… #> $ geoid_bl                      <chr> "370810161022008", "370810168003003", "3… #> $ geoid_co                      <chr> "37081", "37081", "37081", "37081", "370… #> $ file_time_stamp               <date> 2024-09-03, 2024-09-03, 2024-09-03, 202… #> $ release                       <date> 2023-12-01, 2023-12-01, 2023-12-01, 202… # get a county nbm_bl <- get_nbm_bl(geoid_co = "47051") dplyr::glimpse(nbm_bl) #> Rows: 2,146 #> Columns: 21 #> $ geoid_bl                                <chr> "470519601001000", "4705196010… #> $ geoid_st                                <chr> "47", "47", "47", "47", "47", … #> $ geoid_co                                <chr> "47051", "47051", "47051", "47… #> $ state_abbr                              <chr> "TN", "TN", "TN", "TN", "TN", … #> $ cnt_total_locations                     <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 8, NA, 8, 3, 1… #> $ cnt_bead_locations                      <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_copper_locations                    <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_cable_locations                     <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_fiber_locations                     <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_other_locations                     <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_unlicensed_fixed_wireless_locations <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 7, NA, 8, 3, 1… #> $ cnt_licensed_fixed_wireless_locations   <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_LBR_fixed_wireless_locations        <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_terrestrial_locations               <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_25_3                                <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_100_20                              <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_100_100                             <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, 0, NA, 0, 0, 0… #> $ cnt_distcint_frn                        <int> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA… #> $ array_frn                               <list> <NULL>, <NULL>, <NULL>, <NULL… #> $ combo_frn                               <dbl> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA… #> $ release                                 <date> 2023-12-01, 2023-12-01, 2023-…  # get census block covered by an ISP identified by their FRN skymesh <- get_frn_nbm_bl("0027136753") dplyr::glimpse(skymesh) #> Rows: 3 #> Columns: 21 #> $ geoid_bl                                <chr> "390375301004009", "3903755510… #> $ geoid_st                                <chr> "39", "39", "39" #> $ geoid_co                                <chr> "39037", "39037", "39109" #> $ state_abbr                              <chr> "OH", "OH", "OH" #> $ cnt_total_locations                     <int> 13, 7, 15 #> $ cnt_bead_locations                      <int> 13, 6, 15 #> $ cnt_copper_locations                    <int> 9, 2, 10 #> $ cnt_cable_locations                     <int> 10, 0, 0 #> $ cnt_fiber_locations                     <int> 13, 5, 2 #> $ cnt_other_locations                     <int> 0, 0, 0 #> $ cnt_unlicensed_fixed_wireless_locations <int> 13, 7, 15 #> $ cnt_licensed_fixed_wireless_locations   <int> 13, 6, 14 #> $ cnt_LBR_fixed_wireless_locations        <int> 11, 0, 0 #> $ cnt_terrestrial_locations               <int> 13, 6, 15 #> $ cnt_25_3                                <int> 13, 6, 14 #> $ cnt_100_20                              <int> 13, 5, 14 #> $ cnt_100_100                             <int> 13, 5, 5 #> $ cnt_distcint_frn                        <int> 9, 6, 8 #> $ array_frn                               <list> <"0002930980", "0004328688", "… #> $ combo_frn                               <dbl> 1.241130e+19, 7.392885e+18, 6.… #> $ release                                 <date> 2023-12-01, 2023-12-01, 2023-1…
